analyzeResult.content:
54
5: New Scientist 9 January 1975
Eat bicarbonate and smoke less
As he leant nonchalantly against the podium puffing frequently at his favourite fays, American psychologist Professor Stanley Schachter explained -to his enthralled "huntionfee" exactly what makes people smoke. Ile told a recent meeting of the British Psycho- logical Society that some individuals really are addicted to cigarettes, and as such are nicotine machines that need to maintain an adequate input of the drug.
Schachter, whose cool. matter-of- fact style qualifies him as a kind of Kojak figure of science, has been putting his friends, students, and any- one else who cared to join in, through experimental hoops, the results of which imply that in many cases the number of cigarettes smoked is deter- mined by entirely physiological rather than psychological factors. The com- mon idea, most of all among smokers, that more fags are consumed at stress- ful and social times because of psychological reactions is wrong, says Schachter. It all has to do with the acidity of the urine, he says.
In one of his first experiments Schachter divided people into two groups: heavy smokers (more than 20 a day); and light smokers (less than 10). These people smoked special high nicotine cigarettes (con- taining 1.3mg) or weak ones (0.3mg) for periods of about four days. The light smokers hardly changed their habits at all, while the hooked volunteers sank into a bad state: most simply could not smoke enough weak cigarettes to satisfy their needs, and many became extremely irritable, so much so that marriages and other relationships . became threatened. Overall, the heavy smoking group pushed up their consumption of weak fags by about 25 per cent, even though the subjects actively disliked the things. Clearly, something pretty powerful urges these people to smoke more than normal of the cigarettes they think are horrid. Is it the "re- turn to mother's breast oral complex" so beloved of some psychologists? Or is it something more basic and less personal, like a simple chemical re- action in the brain?
.,Swedish researchers have recently demonstrated that, once in the body (of mice at least) nicotine heads . straight for the brain where it hangs around for about five minutes; within the next ten minutes, the brain is more or less depleted of the drug, which by now has passed on its way to the liver and the kidneys, event- ually to be excreted. Which brings us on to urine. According to Professor Arnold Beckett at Chelsea College, London, the acidity of the urine affects the way nicotine is excreted. Acidic urine promotes the rapid re- moval of nicotine from the blood, whereas an alkaline urine slows it up. This being so, Schachter won-
dered whether it would be possible to manipulate the number of cigaret- tes smoked by an addict simply modifying the All of the urine
The answer is, yeor Shiokers who pushed their urine towards acidity by swallowing 10g of vitamin C a day increased their fag consumption by roughly 10 per cent. And if the acidi- fyer used was dilute hydrochloric acid rather than the magic vitamin, the increase was 17 per cent. So, urine acidity (and therefore blood composition) does seem to affect cig- arette use. The question is, where do the psychological factors of stress reduction and social lubrication fit in? Is it possible that the greater cigar- ette smoking rate experienced during stress and at parties is not psycholog- ically based, and that these situations simply alter the acidity of the urine? Sounds crazy, but apparently it is true.
To test the effect of tension on urine acidity Schachter chose to study students in his seminars, which, he admits almost gleefully, "are pretty tense affairs". He divided the students into two groups, one which had to present papers at the seminar, and the others who would simply listen. Measurements on the urine samples showed a seven-fold increase in acidity in the urine of the stressed students 'compared with the relaxed listeners. Perhaps more intriguing was Schachter's discovery that parties too acidified people's urine, by a factor of 10 in some cases.
The ups and downs in cigarette use' of addicted smokers therefore seems to follow the physiological changes wraught by external forces. And as a final proof of this Schachter per- formed one more experiment in which he stressed smokers by a system of electric shocks in a psychological test, a situation which he previously found to provoke a 50 per cent rise in the number of cigarettes smoked, and a similar rise in the number of puffs per fag. If smokers ate, several grammes of sodium bicarbonate (which stabilises urine pII) before entering on the ordeal, cigarette con- sumption remained unchanged! The moral is, if addicted smokers can't face a daily diet of bicarb to help reduce the intake of tar and other combustion prednets from cigarettes, they should switch to a strong brand of fags, the best combination being a high nicotine level with low ..
TIMN 275818
Muscle proteins squeeze quattrinique nerves into action
From their solid, established position in muscle mechanics, the protein twins actin and myosin are now turning up in all sorts of unusual places, particularly in nerves. Boston researchers A. L. Blitz and R. E. Fine now report some detailed studies on the protcin composition of rat cortical synaptosomes (the membrane spheres formed when an axon terminal is snipped off). They confirm the presence of muscle-like proteins in various parts of synaptosome membranes and suggest a role for contractile mechanisms' in neurotransmitter release from vesicles.
Blitz and Fine's rigorous techniques of gel electrophoresis and peptide mapping takes the positive identification of muscle- like proteins in specific areas of nerve tissues a crucial step further. They find that "the termini of rat cortical neurons contain relatively large amounts of pro- teins very similar to actin and to brain tropomyosin in molecular weight and in . primary sequence". In addition, they detect tubulin (the microtubular protein), which, like actin, tropomyosin and myo- sin, appears to be associated with the presynaptic membrane.
The isolated synaptic vesicles (the packets of neurotransmitter) also appear to contain myosin-like protein and tubu- lin; there must be a possibility, however, that these proteins are merely stuck to the surface of the vesicle rather than being an integral part of the membrane.
The dependence on calcium ions of neurotransmitter release, and the inter- ference with this process by substances which adversely affect tubulin both point to the direct involvement of actin- and myosin-like proteins and microtubules in the mechanics of the chemical -stage of nerve cell signalling. But until one can examine more closely the direct interaction of the synaptic vesicies with the inner presynaptic membrane, a com- plete answer must remain elusive. (PNAS, vol 71, p 4472.)
Negatively charged seeds have the secret of life
Indian corn seeds placed on a negatively charged conductor so as to reduce free radical formation retain a 70 per cent germination ability after 30 days com- pared with 10 per cent for normal seeds. Writing in Science (vol 186, p 1123) N. W. Pammenter and his colleagues says that this strongly, corroborates the notion that membrane damage by free radicals (in mitochondria, lysosomes and other organelles) is responsible for at least one facet of ageing, both in plants and animals.
In dry seeds, the normal enzyme repair systems and membrane dynamics do not operate to cancel out the free-radical- inflicted damage. Such repair systems do work in hydrated animal cells, but once the enzyme systems deteriorate, the free radicals can take their toll. Previous ex- periments on mice and drosophila pro- duced similar, but less dramatic, life pro- longation following reduction of free radicals. Maybe vitamin E is good for you after all!
----

Eat bicarbonate and smoke less
As he leant nonchalantly against the
podium puffing frequently at his
favourite fays, American psychologist
Professor Stanley Schachter explained
-to his enthralled "huntionfee" exactly
what makes people smoke. Ile told a
recent meeting of the British Psycho-
logical Society that some individuals
really are addicted to cigarettes, and
as such are nicotine machines that
need to maintain an adequate input
of the drug.
Schachter, whose cool. matter-of-
fact style qualifies him as a kind of
Kojak figure of science, has been
putting his friends, students, and any-
one else who cared to join in, through
experimental hoops, the results of
which imply that in many cases the
number of cigarettes smoked is deter-
mined by entirely physiological rather
than psychological factors. The com-
mon idea, most of all among smokers,
that more fags are consumed at stress-
ful and social times because of
psychological reactions is wrong, says
Schachter. It all has to do with the
acidity of the urine, he says.
In one of his first experiments
Schachter divided people into two
groups: heavy smokers (more than
20 a day); and light smokers (less
than 10). These people smoked
special high nicotine cigarettes (con-
taining 1.3mg) or weak ones (0.3mg)
for periods of about four days. The
light smokers hardly changed their
habits at all, while the hooked
volunteers sank into a bad state: most
simply could not smoke enough weak
cigarettes to satisfy their needs, and
many became extremely irritable, so
much so that marriages and other
relationships . became
threatened.
Overall, the heavy smoking group
pushed up their consumption of weak
fags by about 25 per cent, even
though the subjects actively disliked
the things. Clearly, something pretty
powerful urges these people to smoke
more than normal of the cigarettes
they think are horrid. Is it the "re-
turn to mother's breast oral complex"
so beloved of some psychologists? Or
is it something more basic and less
personal, like a simple chemical re-
action in the brain?
.,Swedish researchers have recently
demonstrated that, once in the body
(of mice at least) nicotine heads
. straight for the brain where it hangs
around for about five minutes; within
the next ten minutes, the brain is
more or less depleted of the drug,
which by now has passed on its way
to the liver and the kidneys, event-
ually to be excreted. Which brings
us on to urine. According to Professor
Arnold Beckett at Chelsea College,
London, the acidity of the urine
affects the way nicotine is excreted.
Acidic urine promotes the rapid re-
moval of nicotine from the blood,
whereas an alkaline urine slows it
up. This being so, Schachter won-
dered whether it would be possible
to manipulate the number of cigaret-
tes smoked by an addict simply
modifying the All of the urine
The answer is, yeor Shiokers who
pushed their urine towards acidity
by swallowing 10g of vitamin C a day
increased their fag consumption by
roughly 10 per cent. And if the acidi-
fyer used was dilute hydrochloric
acid rather than the magic vitamin,
the increase was 17 per cent. So,
urine acidity (and therefore blood
composition) does seem to affect cig-
arette use. The question is, where do
the psychological factors of stress
reduction and social lubrication fit in?
Is it possible that the greater cigar-
ette smoking rate experienced during
stress and at parties is not psycholog-
ically based, and that these situations
simply alter the acidity of the urine?
Sounds crazy, but apparently it is
true.
To test the effect of tension on
urine acidity Schachter chose to
study students in his seminars, which,
he admits almost gleefully, "are
pretty tense affairs". He divided the
students into two groups, one which
had to present papers at the seminar,
and the others who would simply
listen. Measurements on the urine
samples showed a seven-fold increase
in acidity in the urine of the stressed
students 'compared with the relaxed
listeners. Perhaps more intriguing
was Schachter's discovery that parties
too acidified people's urine, by a
factor of 10 in some cases.
The ups and downs in cigarette use'
of addicted smokers therefore seems
to follow the physiological changes
wraught by external forces. And as a
final proof of this Schachter per-
formed one more experiment in which
he stressed smokers by a system of
electric shocks in a psychological test,
a situation which he previously found
to provoke a 50 per cent rise in the
number of cigarettes smoked, and a
similar rise in the number of puffs
per fag. If smokers ate, several
grammes of sodium bicarbonate
(which stabilises urine pII) before
entering on the ordeal, cigarette con-
sumption remained unchanged! The
moral is, if addicted smokers can't
face a daily diet of bicarb to help
reduce the intake of tar and other
combustion prednets from cigarettes,
they should switch to a strong brand
of fags, the best combination being
a high nicotine level with low ..
TIMN 275818
Muscle proteins squeeze
quattrinique nerves into action
From their solid, established position in
muscle mechanics, the protein twins
actin and myosin are now turning up in
all sorts of unusual places, particularly
in nerves. Boston researchers A. L. Blitz
and R. E. Fine now report some detailed
studies on the protcin composition of rat
cortical synaptosomes (the membrane
spheres formed when an axon terminal
is snipped off). They confirm the presence
of muscle-like proteins in various parts
of synaptosome membranes and suggest
a role for contractile mechanisms' in
neurotransmitter release from vesicles.
Blitz and Fine's rigorous techniques of
gel electrophoresis and peptide mapping
takes the positive identification of muscle-
like proteins in specific areas of nerve
tissues a crucial step further. They find
that "the termini of rat cortical neurons
contain relatively large amounts of pro-
teins very similar to actin and to brain
tropomyosin in molecular weight and in
. primary sequence". In addition, they
detect tubulin (the microtubular protein),
which, like actin, tropomyosin and myo-
sin, appears to be associated with the
presynaptic membrane.
The isolated synaptic vesicles (the
packets of neurotransmitter) also appear
to contain myosin-like protein and tubu-
lin; there must be a possibility, however,
that these proteins are merely stuck to
the surface of the vesicle rather than
being an integral part of the membrane.
The dependence on calcium ions of
neurotransmitter release, and the inter-
ference with this process by substances
which adversely affect tubulin both point
to the direct involvement of actin- and
myosin-like proteins and microtubules in
the mechanics of the chemical -stage
of nerve cell signalling. But until one
can examine more closely the direct
interaction of the synaptic vesicies with
the inner presynaptic membrane, a com-
plete answer must remain elusive.
(PNAS, vol 71, p 4472.)
Negatively charged seeds
have the secret of life
Indian corn seeds placed on a negatively
charged conductor so as to reduce free
radical formation retain a 70 per cent
germination ability after 30 days com-
pared with 10 per cent for normal seeds.
Writing in Science (vol 186, p 1123) N. W.
Pammenter and his colleagues says that
this strongly, corroborates the notion
that membrane damage by free radicals
(in mitochondria, lysosomes and other
organelles) is responsible for at least
one facet of ageing, both in plants and
animals.
In dry seeds, the normal enzyme repair
systems and membrane dynamics do not
operate to cancel out the free-radical-
inflicted damage. Such repair systems do
work in hydrated animal cells, but once
the enzyme systems deteriorate, the free
radicals can take their toll. Previous ex-
periments on mice and drosophila pro-
duced similar, but less dramatic, life pro-
longation following reduction of free
radicals. Maybe vitamin E is good for
you after all!

paragraphs.content: As he leant nonchalantly against the podium puffing frequently at his favourite fays, American psychologist Professor Stanley Schachter explained -to his enthralled "huntionfee" exactly what makes people smoke. Ile told a recent meeting of the British Psycho- logical Society that some individuals really are addicted to cigarettes, and as such are nicotine machines that need to maintain an adequate input of the drug.

Schachter, whose cool. matter-of- fact style qualifies him as a kind of Kojak figure of science, has been putting his friends, students, and any- one else who cared to join in, through experimental hoops, the results of which imply that in many cases the number of cigarettes smoked is deter- mined by entirely physiological rather than psychological factors. The com- mon idea, most of all among smokers, that more fags are consumed at stress- ful and social times because of psychological reactions is wrong, says Schachter. It all has to do with the acidity of the urine, he says.

In one of his first experiments Schachter divided people into two groups: heavy smokers (more than 20 a day); and light smokers (less than 10). These people smoked special high nicotine cigarettes (con- taining 1.3mg) or weak ones (0.3mg) for periods of about four days. The light smokers hardly changed their habits at all, while the hooked volunteers sank into a bad state: most simply could not smoke enough weak cigarettes to satisfy their needs, and many became extremely irritable, so much so that marriages and other relationships . became threatened. Overall, the heavy smoking group pushed up their consumption of weak fags by about 25 per cent, even though the subjects actively disliked the things. Clearly, something pretty powerful urges these people to smoke more than normal of the cigarettes they think are horrid. Is it the "re- turn to mother's breast oral complex" so beloved of some psychologists? Or is it something more basic and less personal, like a simple chemical re- action in the brain?

.,Swedish researchers have recently demonstrated that, once in the body (of mice at least) nicotine heads . straight for the brain where it hangs around for about five minutes; within the next ten minutes, the brain is more or less depleted of the drug, which by now has passed on its way to the liver and the kidneys, event- ually to be excreted. Which brings us on to urine. According to Professor Arnold Beckett at Chelsea College, London, the acidity of the urine affects the way nicotine is excreted. Acidic urine promotes the rapid re- moval of nicotine from the blood, whereas an alkaline urine slows it up. This being so, Schachter won-
dered whether it would be possible to manipulate the number of cigaret- tes smoked by an addict simply modifying the All of the urine

The answer is, yeor Shiokers who pushed their urine towards acidity by swallowing 10g of vitamin C a day increased their fag consumption by roughly 10 per cent. And if the acidi- fyer used was dilute hydrochloric acid rather than the magic vitamin, the increase was 17 per cent. So, urine acidity (and therefore blood composition) does seem to affect cig- arette use. The question is, where do the psychological factors of stress reduction and social lubrication fit in? Is it possible that the greater cigar- ette smoking rate experienced during stress and at parties is not psycholog- ically based, and that these situations simply alter the acidity of the urine? Sounds crazy, but apparently it is true.

To test the effect of tension on urine acidity Schachter chose to study students in his seminars, which, he admits almost gleefully, "are pretty tense affairs". He divided the students into two groups, one which had to present papers at the seminar, and the others who would simply listen. Measurements on the urine samples showed a seven-fold increase in acidity in the urine of the stressed students 'compared with the relaxed listeners. Perhaps more intriguing was Schachter's discovery that parties too acidified people's urine, by a factor of 10 in some cases.

The ups and downs in cigarette use' of addicted smokers therefore seems to follow the physiological changes wraught by external forces. And as a final proof of this Schachter per- formed one more experiment in which he stressed smokers by a system of electric shocks in a psychological test, a situation which he previously found to provoke a 50 per cent rise in the number of cigarettes smoked, and a similar rise in the number of puffs per fag. If smokers ate, several grammes of sodium bicarbonate (which stabilises urine pII) before entering on the ordeal, cigarette con- sumption remained unchanged! The moral is, if addicted smokers can't face a daily diet of bicarb to help reduce the intake of tar and other combustion prednets from cigarettes, they should switch to a strong brand of fags, the best combination being a high nicotine level with low ..
Muscle proteins squeeze quattrinique nerves into action

From their solid, established position in muscle mechanics, the protein twins actin and myosin are now turning up in all sorts of unusual places, particularly in nerves. Boston researchers A. L. Blitz and R. E. Fine now report some detailed studies on the protcin composition of rat cortical synaptosomes (the membrane spheres formed when an axon terminal is snipped off). They confirm the presence of muscle-like proteins in various parts of synaptosome membranes and suggest a role for contractile mechanisms' in neurotransmitter release from vesicles.

Blitz and Fine's rigorous techniques of gel electrophoresis and peptide mapping takes the positive identification of muscle- like proteins in specific areas of nerve tissues a crucial step further. They find that "the termini of rat cortical neurons contain relatively large amounts of pro- teins very similar to actin and to brain tropomyosin in molecular weight and in . primary sequence". In addition, they detect tubulin (the microtubular protein), which, like actin, tropomyosin and myo- sin, appears to be associated with the presynaptic membrane.

The isolated synaptic vesicles (the packets of neurotransmitter) also appear to contain myosin-like protein and tubu- lin; there must be a possibility, however, that these proteins are merely stuck to the surface of the vesicle rather than being an integral part of the membrane.

The dependence on calcium ions of neurotransmitter release, and the inter- ference with this process by substances which adversely affect tubulin both point to the direct involvement of actin- and myosin-like proteins and microtubules in the mechanics of the chemical -stage of nerve cell signalling. But until one can examine more closely the direct interaction of the synaptic vesicies with the inner presynaptic membrane, a com- plete answer must remain elusive. (PNAS, vol 71, p 4472.)
Negatively charged seeds have the secret of life

Indian corn seeds placed on a negatively charged conductor so as to reduce free radical formation retain a 70 per cent germination ability after 30 days com- pared with 10 per cent for normal seeds. Writing in Science (vol 186, p 1123) N. W. Pammenter and his colleagues says that this strongly, corroborates the notion that membrane damage by free radicals (in mitochondria, lysosomes and other organelles) is responsible for at least one facet of ageing, both in plants and animals.

In dry seeds, the normal enzyme repair systems and membrane dynamics do not operate to cancel out the free-radical- inflicted damage. Such repair systems do work in hydrated animal cells, but once the enzyme systems deteriorate, the free radicals can take their toll. Previous ex- periments on mice and drosophila pro- duced similar, but less dramatic, life pro- longation following reduction of free radicals. Maybe vitamin E is good for you after all!
